title: Algebraic Homomorphism Schema
description: A precise schema defining algebraic homomorphisms within the UOR framework, focusing on structure-preserving maps between algebraic domains

id.description: Unique identifier for the algebraic homomorphism schema

description.const: A structure-preserving map between algebraic domains that respects the relevant algebraic operations
description.description: Description of the algebraic homomorphism concept

sourceDomain.description: The domain from which the homomorphism maps

domainUri.description: URI reference to the domain schema

operations.description: Operations defined in the source domain

arity.description: Arity of the operation (unary, binary, etc.)

targetDomain.description: The domain to which the homomorphism maps

domainUri.description: URI reference to the domain schema

operations.description: Operations defined in the target domain

arity.description: Arity of the operation (unary, binary, etc.)

formalDefinition.const: A map φ: S → T where S is the source domain and T is the target domain, such that φ preserves the structure of the operations in S

representationFormula.description: Formula for representing the homomorphism, if applicable

preservationAxioms.description: Axioms that define the structure preservation

interpretation.description: Interpretation of what this axiom means

examples.axiomFormula: φ(a * b) = φ(a) * φ(b) for all a, b in S
examples.interpretation: The homomorphism preserves the group operation

examples.axiomFormula: φ(a + b) = φ(a) + φ(b) for all a, b in S
φ(a * b) = φ(a) * φ(b) for all a, b in S

operationPreservation.description: Specific operations preserved by the homomorphism

targetOperation.description: Corresponding operation in the target domain

preservationFormula.description: Formula expressing how the operation is preserved

propertiesPreserved.description: Algebraic properties preserved by the homomorphism

propertiesNotPreserved.description: Algebraic properties that may not be preserved

kernelProperties.description: Properties of the kernel of the homomorphism

definition.const: The kernel of a homomorphism φ: S → T is the set of all elements in S that map to the identity element in T: ker(φ) = {s ∈ S | φ(s) = e_T}

isNormal.description: Whether the kernel forms a normal subgroup (for group homomorphisms)

isIdeal.description: Whether the kernel forms an ideal (for ring homomorphisms)

substructureType.description: Type of algebraic substructure formed by the kernel

fundamentalTheorem.const: For a homomorphism φ: S → T, the quotient structure S/ker(φ) is isomorphic to the image of φ in T

implications.description: Implications of kernel properties for the homomorphism
examples: Injectivity is equivalent to having a trivial kernel
The kernel determines the partition of the source domain into equivalence classes
The structure of the kernel constrains the possible structures of the image

imageProperties.description: Properties of the image of the homomorphism

definition.const: The image of a homomorphism φ: S → T is the set of all elements in T that are mapped to by some element in S: img(φ) = {t ∈ T | ∃s ∈ S such that φ(s) = t}

isSubgroup.description: Whether the image forms a subgroup (for group homomorphisms)

isSubring.description: Whether the image forms a subring (for ring homomorphisms)

substructureType.description: Type of algebraic substructure formed by the image

implications.description: Implications of image properties for the homomorphism
examples: Surjectivity is equivalent to the image being the entire target domain
The image inherits some but not all properties from the source domain
The structure of the image reflects the source modulo the kernel

examples.definition: A bijective homomorphism (both injective and surjective)
properties: Has an inverse that is also a homomorphism
Establishes complete structural equivalence between domains

examples.definition: A homomorphism from a domain to itself
properties: May reveal internal symmetries of the structure

examples.definition: An isomorphism from a domain to itself
properties: Forms a group under composition (the automorphism group)
Represents the symmetries of the algebraic structure
Embeds the source domain isomorphically into a subdomain of the target
Image is the entire target domain
Target is a quotient of the source

primeDecomposition.description: The prime decomposition structure of homomorphisms in the UOR framework

elementaryHomomorphisms.description: Basic prime homomorphisms that serve as building blocks

irreducibilityProof.description: Reference to proof that this homomorphism is irreducible

examples.name: Projection homomorphism
examples.description: Maps an element to its equivalence class in a quotient structure
examples.irreducibilityProof: Cannot be further decomposed while preserving homomorphism properties

examples.name: Embedding homomorphism
examples.description: Maps an element into a larger structure while preserving its properties

examples.name: Character homomorphism
examples.description: Maps from a group to the multiplicative group of a field

examples.name: Kernel expansion
examples.effect: Expands the kernel by composing with a quotient map

examples.name: Domain restriction
examples.effect: Restricts to a subdomain while preserving homomorphism properties

examples.name: Range corestriction
examples.effect: Limits the codomain to the image of the homomorphism

decompositionTheorem.const: Any homomorphism can be factored as the composition of a surjective homomorphism followed by an injective homomorphism: φ = i ∘ p, where p: S → S/ker(φ) is the natural projection and i: S/ker(φ) → img(φ) is the canonical isomorphism
decompositionTheorem.description: Theorem describing the factorization of homomorphisms

canonicalForm.const: The canonical form of a homomorphism consists of its kernel-cokernel decomposition, which fully characterizes its structure up to isomorphism

uniquenessProperties.const: The factorization of a homomorphism through its image is unique up to isomorphism of the intermediate structure

examples.propertyDescription: Any homomorphism whose kernel contains a normal subgroup N factors uniquely through the quotient by N
Any function from generators to a structure extends uniquely to a homomorphism from the free object
Homomorphisms to a product correspond bijectively to tuples of homomorphisms to the factors

examples.perspective: Viewing homomorphisms through their algebraic properties
Viewing homomorphisms through preservation of structure
Viewing homomorphisms as morphisms in a category
Viewing homomorphisms as algorithms for structure mapping

measureDescription.description: Description of what the measure quantifies

formula.description: Formula or method for calculating the measure

examples.measureDescription: Size or dimension of the kernel, measuring information loss
examples.formula: For finite structures: |ker(φ)|; For vector spaces: dim(ker(φ))

examples.measureDescription: Size or dimension of the image, measuring information preservation
examples.formula: For finite structures: |img(φ)|; For vector spaces: dim(img(φ))

examples.measureDescription: Degree to which the homomorphism preserves algebraic structure
examples.formula: Ratio of preserved structural properties to total properties

examples.measureDescription: Complexity of the prime factorization of the homomorphism
examples.formula: Number of irreducible factors in the canonical decomposition

examples.measureDescription: Minimum number of elementary transformations to reach this homomorphism from an identity map
examples.formula: Min(n) such that φ can be expressed as the composition of n elementary transformations

examples.applicationDescription: Using homomorphisms to preserve structure while transforming data
examples: Homomorphic encryption allowing computation on encrypted data
Isomorphism problems as basis for security

examples.applicationDescription: Using homomorphisms to represent abstract structures in concrete forms
examples: Group representations as homomorphisms to matrix groups

examples.applicationDescription: Using homomorphisms to connect field extensions with their symmetries
examples: Field automorphisms as elements of Galois groups

examples.applicationDescription: Using homomorphisms to define and analyze error-correcting codes
examples: Linear codes as images of homomorphisms
Homomorphism weight analysis for distance properties

examples.theoremStatement: If φ: S → T is a homomorphism, then S/ker(φ) ≅ img(φ)
examples.significance: Provides the canonical decomposition of a homomorphism into a surjection followed by an injection

examples.theoremStatement: If H is a substructure of S and N is a normal substructure of S, then (H∩N) is normal in H and H/(H∩N) ≅ (HN)/N
examples.significance: Relates quotients of substructures to substructures of quotients

examples.theoremStatement: If N and K are normal substructures of S with N ⊆ K, then (S/N)/(K/N) ≅ S/K
examples.significance: Shows how quotients of quotients relate to direct quotients

examples.theoremStatement: Any homomorphism from a substructure can be extended to a homomorphism from the whole structure if the target has suitable properties
examples.significance: Enables construction of homomorphisms through extension principles

compositionProperties.description: Properties related to composition of homomorphisms

compositionRule.const: The composition of homomorphisms is a homomorphism. If φ: A → B and ψ: B → C are homomorphisms, then ψ∘φ: A → C is a homomorphism

categoryStructure.const: Algebraic domains and their homomorphisms form a category, with objects as domains and morphisms as homomorphisms

decompositionAlgorithm.description: Algorithm for decomposing a homomorphism into simpler components
